prompt: What is a hematocrit?
choices: Percent of red blood cells in a blood sample
An abnormal red blood cell resulting from a genetic disorder
Stem cell that gives rise to the agranulocytes

prompt: What are the formed elements?
Which cell type is an agranulocyte?
What is the primary function of lymphocytes?
choices: To produce enzymes that dissolve blood clots.
To release substances that initiate blood clots.

prompt: Which of the following functions as a phagocyte?
What type of antigens are found on the surface of red blood cells of a person with type AB blood?
choices: Neither antigens A nor antigens B

prompt: What is the rarest ABO blood type in the United States?
What determines an individual's blood type?
choices: Proteins (antibodies) on the surface of red blood cells
Proteins (antigens) on the surface of white blood cells
Proteins (antigens) on the surfaces of red blood cells

prompt: In what situation might erythroblastosis fetalis occur?
choices: A second Rh-positive fetus developing in an Rh-negative woman
A first Rh-positive fetus developing in an Rh-negative woman
A second Rh-negative fetus developing in an Rh-negative woman
A first Rh-negative fetus developing in an Rh-negative woman

prompt: What blood type can successfully be given to a person with type AB blood?
choices: Only one of the blood types
Only two of the blood types

prompt: Blood vessels called__________ carry blood toward the heart, and__________ carry blood away from the heart.
What is a function of the pulmonary circuit?
choices: It carries oxygen-poor blood to the heart.
It carries oxygen-poor blood to the tissues.
It carries oxygen-poor blood to the lungs.
It carries oxygen-poor blood from the tissues.

prompt: What is a function of the systemic circuit?
choices: It carries oxygen-rich blood to the heart.
It carries oxygen-poor blood to the tissues.
It carries oxygen-rich blood from the lungs.
It carries oxygen-poor blood to the heart.

prompt: During ventricular contraction, what is the status of the atrioventricular valves?
choices: The mitral valve is opened and the tricuspid valve is closed.
The tricuspid valve is open and the mitral valve is closed.
The mitral and tricuspid valves both are closed.
The mitral and tricuspid valves both are open.

prompt: Name the tough outermost layer of the sac that surrounds the heart.
What forms the skeleton of the heart?
choices: Fibrous connective tissue in the endocardium
Fibrous connective tissue around the valves

prompt: Blood flowing from the vena cavae to the pulmonary trunk passes through what series of structures?
choices: Right atrium, pulmonary valve, right ventricle, tricuspid valve
Right atrium, tricuspid valve, right ventricle, pulmonary valve
Right ventricle, tricuspid valve, right atrium, pulmonary valve
Right ventricle, pulmonary valve, right atrium, tricuspid valve

prompt: What layer lines the chambers of the heart?
Name the layers of the the wall of the heart and surrounding structures from deep to superficial.
choices: Myocardium, endocardium, epicardium, fibrous pericardium, pericardial cavity, parietal pericardium
Fibrous pericardium, parietal pericardium, pericardial cavity, epicardium, myocardium, endocardium
Epicardium, myocardium, endocardium, pericardial cavity, parietal pericardium, fibrous pericardium
Endocardium, myocardium, epicardium, pericardial cavity, parietal pericardium, fibrous pericardium

prompt: Blood entering the right atrium comes from what structure(s)?
What happens in the condition called mitral valve prolapse?
choices: The cusps of the mitral valve become immovable.
The mitral valve has hardened, narrowing the opening into the ventricle.
One or more cusps bulge into the left ventricle during ventricular relaxation.
One or more cusps bulge into the left atrium during ventricular contraction.

prompt: What chambers of the heart will contain oxygen-poor blood?
Which valve is located between the left atrium and left ventricle?
Constriction of the__________ reduces blood flow to the myocardium of the right side of the heart. This decrease in blood flow can result in__________.
choices: left coronary artery; mitral valve prolapse

prompt: What is the correct sequence of components of the cardiac conduction system?
choices: AV node → SA node → Purkinje fibers→ AV bundle
AV node → AV bundle → Purkinje fibers → SA node
SA node → Purkinje fibers → AV node → AV bundle
SA node → AV node → AV bundle → Purkinje fibers

prompt: What is the normal pacemaker of the heart?
Sounds from the closing of the__________ valve are best heard at the fifth intercostal space just to the left of the sternum.
What is the effect of nitric oxide in blood vessels?
choices: Causes increased permeability and leakiness of capillary walls
Causes decreased permeability and leakiness of capillary walls

prompt: What blood vessels hold the greatest volume of blood?
What is described by the Frank-Starling law of the heart?
choices: That the SA node will act as the pacemaker
That the quantity of blood that enters the heart equals the quantity that is pumped out
That blood will only flow through the coronary circulation during diastole
That cardiac output is equal to heart rate times stroke volume

prompt: Which of the following is increased when sympathetic stimulation to the heart increases?
What is preload?
choices: Amount of blood pumped by each ventricle during each cardiac cycle
Amount of stretch of myocardial cells prior to contraction
Pressure in arteries, against which the heart is pumping blood
The amount of fluid leaking from capillaries, diminishing blood volume

prompt: What is the effect of vasoconstriction?
How is stroke volume calculated?
How is pulse pressure calculated?
choices: PP = systolic pressure x diastolic pressure

prompt: Name two branches of the right coronary artery.
choices: Posterior interventricular artery and right marginal branch
Anterior interventricular artery and circumflex branch
Anterior interventricular artery and posterior interventricular artery
Right marginal branch and circumflex branch

prompt: Valves help to ensure one-way blood flow in the__________.
What is the function of the papillary muscles of the heart?
choices: To assist in the ejection of blood
To help conduct cardiac impulses throughout the ventricular myocardium
To prevent atrioventricular valves from prolapsing
To hold the semilunar valves closed during ventricular diastole

prompt: During the cardiac cycle, at the time of highest ventricular pressure, what is the status of the heart valves?
choices: Atrioventricular valves are closed; semilunar valves are open.
Atrioventricular valves are open; semilunar valves are closed.
Atrioventricular valves are open; semilunar valves are open.
Atrioventricular valves are closed; semilunar valves are closed.

prompt: What causes the first heart sound? When does this occur?
choices: Closure of the semilunar valves at the beginning of ventricular diastole
Closure of the atrioventricular valves soon after the beginning of ventricular systole
Closure of the semilunar valves soon after the beginning of ventricular systole
Closure of the atrioventricular valves at the beginning of ventricular diastole

prompt: The apical heartbeat is heard by listening between the fifth and sixth ribs about 7.5 cm left of the midline.
The coronary sinus drains blood from the wall of the heart into the left atrium.
What are pathogens?
choices: Agents that alter DNA base sequences

prompt: What role does the lymphatic system have in influencing body fluids?
choices: It adds hypotonic fluid to any tissue fluid that has an elevated solute concentration.
It moves tissue fluid from one area to another, ensuring that all tissue fluid levels are consistent.
It provides the fluid needed to bathe tissue cells in nutrient-rich fluid.
It moves excess tissue fluid from the interstitium to the bloodstream.

prompt: The structure of a lymphatic vessel is most similar to that of a(n)__________.
Name the two collecting ducts that drain the lymphatic trunks.
choices: Thoracic duct and right lymphatic duct
Lumbar duct and left lymphatic duct

prompt: From the collecting ducts, lymph enters__________ and becomes part of the__________.
In what situation will there be an increase in lymph formation?
choices: Increased osmotic pressure in blood capillaries.
Increased hydrostatic pressure in tissue fluid.
Decreased protein concentration in tissue fluid.

prompt: What is one function of lymph?
choices: Return of proteins to the tissue fluid.
Transport of foreign particles to the kidneys.
Transport of foreign particles to the lymph nodes.
Transport of oxygen and carbon dioxide.

prompt: Lymph nodes are located throughout the body except in the__________.
Where are the supratrochlear lymph nodes located?
Which of the following cells function as phagocytes?
How do viruses differ from other pathogens?
choices: They are larger than most other pathogens.
They are more likely to cause life-threatening infections.
They are not capable of reproducing outside a living cell.

prompt: What type of phagocytic cells are circulating in the blood?

Which of the following occurs during an adaptive immune response?
Following a tissue transplant, the transplant recipients typically need to take medications to__________.
What cell types are primarily responsible for immunity?
What is the relationship between antigens and antibodies?
choices: The presence of an antigen triggers the production of antibodies.
The presence of antibodies triggers the production of antigens.
Antigens function to destroy or neutralize antibodies.
Antibodies can be foreign cells, proteins, or other large molecules. Antigens are large proteins made by B cells.

prompt: Antibody actions against antigens include__________ in which the antibodies bind to antigen, forming an insoluble complex that can be phagocytized.
Anaphylactic shock is a risk with what type of hypersensitivity?
